title: How to Get a Good Job

steps.title: Figure out your skill set.
steps.content: Figure out your skill set. Sit down and make a list so you can narrow down your search. You can include your degree (if you have one), your job experience, and any vocational training you have. [1] X Expert Source Jennifer Landis-Santos, PCC, NBHWC Certified Career Counselor & Wellness Coach Expert Interview. 6 April 2022. You can also include “soft skills,” like professionalism, responsiveness, and friendliness. [2] X Expert Source Kent Lee Career & Executive Coach Expert Interview. 2 April 2020. Once you figure out the skills you already have, you can decide on a career path that’s right for you. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Jot down your likes and dislikes.
steps.content: Jot down your likes and dislikes. What did you like about your past jobs? What did you really dislike? Make a list of things both good and bad so you can keep them in mind as you search through opportunities. [4] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Identify your ideal work style.
steps.content: Identify your ideal work style. Do you like working from home, or would you rather go into the office? Are you a social butterfly who’s good at talking to a variety of people, or do you prefer backend work with less customer interaction? Answer these questions to narrow down your search when you find open positions. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Academy of Family Physicians Organization devoted to improving the health of patients, families, and communities Go to source You might also consider what amount of responsibility you would like in your ideal job. Are you comfortable answering phone calls or emails after the workday is over, for example? [6] X Expert Source Jennifer Landis-Santos, PCC, NBHWC Certified Career Counselor & Wellness Coach Expert Interview. 6 April 2022.

steps.title: Reach out to other professionals.
steps.content: Reach out to other professionals. Networking is your best way to find a job opportunity. If you know people in the field, shoot them an email and tell them you’re looking for a new job. If you went to school with anyone working right now, ask them if they know of any openings. Word-of-mouth is the number one way people find a job in today’s market. [7] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Search for opportunities online.
steps.content: Search for opportunities online. You’ll find tons of jobs posted online that you can apply for quickly. Look at sites like Glassdoor, Monter, Indeed, LinkedIn, Google Jobs, and Ladders to start your search. You can enter in a keyword or a location to find the perfect job for you. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Look for company reviews.
steps.content: Look for company reviews. A good job is more than just the pay—you’ll want to ensure that you’re going to be happy there, too. Check out the company on Glassdoor or LinkedIn to see what employees are saying about the job duties, benefits, and company culture. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Consider the pay and the benefits.
steps.content: Consider the pay and the benefits. What would you be getting paid? How many hours would you work? Does the job provide benefits? Is there paid time off or vacation time? Is there any room for growth within the company? It’s up to you to decide if you’d like to accept, reject, or negotiate the offer that you’re presented with. [10] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Perfect your resumé.
steps.content: Perfect your resumé. It’s your first impression for your potential employer. Make sure the format is clean and easy to read, list your skills in bullet points, and have your work and school experience front and center. [11] X Expert Source Kent Lee Career & Executive Coach Expert Interview. 2 April 2020. Consider having a friend or family member look it over before sending it out. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Clean up your social media accounts.
steps.content: Clean up your social media accounts. Many employers will search you up online before hiring you. If they find something they don’t like (pictures of you smoking, drinking, or partying), it could affect their decision. Make sure your social media accounts are set to private or clean them up before you start applying for jobs. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Make a good impression at the interview.
steps.content: Make a good impression at the interview. It’s your time to prove yourself to the company. Wear an appropriate outfit for the job (usually slightly more dressed up than you would be on a typical work day). Show up on time and shake your interviewer’s hand, then answer the questions as best you can. When the interview is over, shake their hand again and thank them for their time. [14] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Business Review Online and print journal covering topics related to business management practices Go to source

steps.title: Healthcare jobs often pay the most.
steps.content: Healthcare jobs often pay the most. In fact, a 2020 report states that anesthesiologists and surgeons get paid the most out of any job out there. However, you do need a doctorate degree before getting these jobs, and that much school can take a lot of time. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Financial and IT managers get paid very well.
steps.content: Financial and IT managers get paid very well. This field is often called “middle management.” If you’re a middle manager, you’ll take direction from your boss and give direction to your employees. You can work your way up to being a manager in most companies, so it’s a great goal to keep in mind as you enter the workforce. [16] X Research source
